findings.description: The procureService function allows anyone who sends enough ETH to become the new owner of the contract.
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all BONUS_VALID criteria: 1) Concrete exploit with specific steps, 2) No trusted role compromise required, 3) No existing mitigation, 4) In scope, 5) Not a design choice, 6) Material impact (unauthorized ownership transfer).

findings.description: The return value of credential.transferFrom() is not checked.
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all BONUS_VALID criteria: 1) Concrete exploit with specific steps, 2) No trusted role compromise required, 3) No existing mitigation, 4) In scope, 5) Not a design choice, 6) Material impact (becoming owner without paying token cost).

findings.description: The procureService function is payable and accepts ETH, but there is no function to withdraw ETH from the contract.
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all BONUS_VALID criteria: 1) Concrete exploit with specific steps, 2) No trusted role compromise required, 3) No existing mitigation, 4) In scope, 5) Not a design choice, 6) Material impact (permanent loss of funds).

findings.description: The function uses serviceCost for the token transfer amount but then immediately overwrites it with the caller-provided current_servicecost parameter.
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all BONUS_VALID criteria: 1) Concrete exploit with specific steps, 2) No trusted role compromise required, 3) No existing mitigation, 4) In scope, 5) Not a design choice, 6) Material impact (service becomes unusable).

target_assessment.type_match_reasoning: The target vulnerability (front_running/race condition) was not mentioned in any of the findings.

notes: The analysis identified several valid security concerns but missed the target vulnerability (front_running/race condition). All findings were well-explained and met the strict criteria for BONUS_VALID.
